importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the sexual assault at Gettysburg College occurred, marking the beginning of a long legal and emotional journey for the victim and the case's eventual resolution.
The year when Ian Cleary sent the Facebook message 'So I raped you' to Shannon Keeler, reigniting her efforts to pursue justice and leading to renewed legal action.

The year Shannon Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story highlighting the reluctance of prosecutors to pursue campus sexual assault cases, which contributed to Cleary being indicted shortly afterward.
The date Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy-related charge, which ultimately enabled authorities to track him down and initiate extradition proceedings.
The date of the sentencing in court, when Ian Cleary was given a two to four-year prison sentence for the 2013 sexual assault, marking a significant milestone in the case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Cleary was detained in France, leading to his extradition and the eventual sentencing, highlighting international cooperation in prosecuting serious crimes.
The period during which Keeler publicly shared her story, influencing prosecutorial decisions and exposing systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases.
The timeline from the assault to the eventual prosecution, illustrating the long delay in justice due to institutional and procedural barriers.

keyTakeAways: The case underscores the long delays in prosecuting campus sexual assault cases, with victims often facing years of silence and lack of support.
A victim’s public advocacy — such as Shannon Keeler’s AP story — can play a pivotal role in prompting legal action years after the incident.
The victim’s emotional and psychological trauma persisted for over a decade, with the legal system's failure to act early causing lasting harm.
The perpetrator, Ian Cleary, admitted guilt and expressed remorse, but his mental health history and the passage of time influenced the sentencing being below state guidelines.

Cleary’s extradition from France highlights the challenges of tracking down perpetrators who flee or hide online and legally, but also shows that international legal systems can collaborate effectively.
The message 'So I raped you' sent in 2019 was not an act of denial but a calculated effort at atonement through a 12-step program, revealing complex dynamics of accountability and mental health.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison for sexually assaulting a woman, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013. After years of silence, Keeler pursued charges, which were initially delayed due to institutional reluctance to prosecute campus sexual assaults. Her public advocacy in 2021 — including an Associated Press story — helped prompt renewed legal action. Cleary was extradited from France in 2024 after being detained on a vagrancy charge, and in 2025, he pleaded guilty and was sentenced by Senior Judge Kevin Hess, who considered his remorse and mental health history. The case highlights systemic failures in campus sexual assault prosecution, the long-term trauma of victims, and the role of public awareness in achieving justice after years of inaction.
title: Man Sentenced for 2013 Campus Sexual Assault After 12-Year Delay
